section.name: Getting Started For Contributors
section.p: Follow these instructions to get configured to build and work with the Apache Harmony source code. To get the Harmony code and build it, follow these steps:

a.href: #2. Checking out the Federated Build Tree

section.p: After successfully building the source code, you will be able to run Java* applications with Harmony.
If you only need specific parts of the source code and not the whole HDK (Harmony Java developer's kit), you can follow component-wise instructions.

The build is evolving. If you come across a problem, double-check the mailing list: your issue may have been already discovered and resolved. Otherwise, you can write a new mail to ask for help and support.

subsection.name: 1. Prerequisites
subsection.p: The tools you must have to be able to work with Harmony are:
Note

If you are working from behind a firewall, you may need to configure the proxy setting for ant and svn tools.
For the ant tool, set the ANT_OPTS environment variable to point to:
-Dhttp.proxyHost=<host>
-Dhttp.proxyPort=<proxy>
For the svn tool, follow the instructions appropriate to the version of the tool you use. For example, edit ~/.subversion/servers file for console version of svn.

Optional (but recommended) prerequisite is an Eclipse Java Compiler (ECJ), version 3.2 or higher. You need to download standalone ecj.jar and put it to ANT_HOME/lib directory. Alternatively, you can switch to any other Java 1.5 compiler supported by Ant via overriding hy.javac.compiler property.

The other prerequisites for building Harmony differ by platform. For examples of platform-specific setup instructions, please see these community maintained descriptions. Below is a generic guideline for each platform.
To learn which platforms are currently supported, see the Porting Matrix.

ul.li:
Optionally, an external compiler, such as:
Microsoft 32-bit C/C++ Compiler, version 7 or higher
Intel C++ Compiler, version 9.0

gcc compiler, version 3.3.3 or higher
Versions below 3.3.3 have not been tested but might work.

subsection.p: The build system requires additional software and libraries shared across different parts of the build or specific for individual build parts. The list is evolving, so the safest way to get and configure all the required software is to let the build download it from the Internet.
Here is the list of additional tools required for one of the build parts, DRLVM. The list applies to Windows and Linux users.

ul.li: Xalan-Java, version 2.7.0 (taken from class libraries component)
Cpp Tasks collection, version 1.0 beta 3 or higher (downloaded)
Ant-Contrib collection of tasks, version 0.6 or higher (downloaded)
Zlib library, binaries, version 1.2.1 or higher (downloaded)

subsection.p:
You can download these resources prior to building DRLVM, unpack them, and specify the resulting locations by using the environment variables, as described in the
README file , step 3.3.1. In this file, you can find instructions on how to point to local versions instead of making the build download new ones from the net.
Because the list of sotware is subject to change, we do not recommend that you download the software and not let the build do that for you.

subsection.name: 2. Checking out the Federated Build Tree
subsection.p: The Harmony codebase is divided into many separate parts. To create a working JRE, you need a class library and a virtual machine. To obtain these tools, use the federated build tree and then work within the class library directory and the VM directory as you choose. Currently, the federated build uses the DRLVM virtual machine.
To check out the federated build, use the following command:

This command checks out a directory structure that contains working_classlib and working_vm directories. After you populate the source trees in the next step, working_classlib will be the checkout of the class library SVN tree and working_vm will be the checkout of the DRLVM SVN tree.
Note

If the root of the federated build is multiple levels deep in your file system, the very long paths within class library might result in a SVN checkout failure on Windows. The solution is to move the tree upwards in your file system or switch operating systems.

subsection.name: 3. Starting the Federated Build
subsection.p: Now you should be ready to build the code. For the first time you build, you might want to fetch all the dependencies. If you do not, or if in the future a new dependency is added, the build will tell you what to do, so that you can do this step periodically. To fetch the dependencies and check out, build, and package snapshots of the JRE and HDK, type the following command in the root directory of the federated build:

This variant of command downloads all the required third-party components that can be distributed under licences different from the Apache license; see THIRD_PARTY_NOTICES.txt in the root directory for details. This is only needed during your first build. For subsequent builds, just type:
Note

If you choose to build from the federated build root, you may need to increase the Java heap available to Ant. We suggest setting the "ANT_OPTS" environment variable as ANT_OPTS='-Xms256m -Xmx512m' in the manner appropriate for your operating system.

Because running Ant in the root directory builds the full JDK, it can be inconvenient for a developer focused on a specific area. If you are not interested in building the full HDK, follow the detailed instructions to build each JRE component separately.

section.name: Detailed Building Instructions
section.p: If you do not need to build the whole HDK and did not execute ant in step 3, follow these instructions to build each component in turn and assemble the JRE from them. The building procedure consists of the following steps:

li.a: Build the class library source code.
Combine class libraries and VM into JRE.

subsection.name: 1. Populating the Source Trees
subsection.p: To populate the source trees, use the target located in the federated build build.xml script. Type the following command in the root directory of the federated build:

The given command checks out class library and DRLVM into the working_classlib and working_vm directories respectively, at the same SVN version of the build.xml file . The source trees are large, therefore a checkout can take a very long time.

subsection.name: 2. Updating the Source Trees
subsection.p: Any time going forward, you can bring any directory to current SVN revision simply by doing svn update in any directory.

The aforementioned commands are valid checkouts of the class library and DRLVM. After executing svn update, your tree will reflect any modifications made to the SVN repository. If you are a project committer, you can make commits from within this tree, as it is a normal SVN checkout.
Note
If you fail to rebuild class library after the svn update command, clean previous build results:

subsection.name: 3. Building the Class Library
subsection.p: Now you should be ready to build the code. First build the class library because DRLVM has a dependency on it and also assembles a working JRE as part of its build.

For the first time you build, you might want to fetch all the class library dependencies. If you do not, or if in the future a new dependency is added, the build will tell you what to do, so that you can do this step periodically. To fetch the class library dependencies and then build class library, use the following commands:
You can only test the class libraries in case you have a virtual machine. If you do, run the following command to get the full test suite for the class library:
You can use a VM other than DRLVM, see Combining JRE from Built Components. If you want to use DRLVM, proceed with the instruction to build it.

subsection.name: 4. Building DRLVM

ol.li:
Enter the build directory.
After building the class library, build DRLVM assembling a working JRE. For that, return to the root of the federated build and switch into the working_vm directory, then to the build directory:
$ cd working_vm/build

ul.li:
Edit drlvm.properties
Tell the DRLVM build where to find the class library: rename the file drlvm.properties.example in the DRLVM build directory to drlvm.properties.
$ cp drlvm.properties.example drlvm.properties
This file contains a property definition that tells DRLVM build to use the class library in working_classlib. If you want to point to another build of the class library, override the given file on the command line.
Double-check that the resulting properties file has deploy.canonical.flag set to TRUE. This value enables the build to create the deploy/jre/bin directory. Further building procedures require this directory.

Select the compiler.
You can switch between the different compilers and modes by using the environment variables, as follows:
Compiler
On Windows
On Linux
MSVC compiler
set CXX=msvc
N/A
Intel(R) compiler
set CXX=icl
export CXX=icc
GCC compiler
N/A
export CXX=gcc

Select the working mode: debug or release.
By default, the debug configuration is used. To switch to the release mode, do:
On Windows: > set BUILD_CFG=release > build.bat
On Linux: $ BUILD_CFG=release ./build.bat

ol.li:
Fetch the dependencies.
Before starting the build, fetch the dependencies. Note that this can take a long time.
On Windows: C:...\trunk\working_vm\build>build.bat update
On Linux: $ sh build.sh update

Build the code.
To proceed with the build, run the following:
On Windows: C:...\trunk\working_vm\build>build.bat
On Linux: $ sh build.sh

Run the acceptance tests.
To complete the operation, run the following acceptance tests:
On Windows: C:...\trunk\working_vm\build>build.bat test
On Linux: $ sh build.sh test

subsection.p: At this point, the DRLVM build is complete. A full JRE is in the deploy/jre subdirectory of the build directory.
For example, you can run JRE with the -version argument to see its version:
subsection.pre: $ cd deploy/jre/bin $ ./java -version Apache Harmony Launcher: (c) Copyright 1991, 2006 The Apache Software Foundation or its licensors, as applicable. java version "1.5.0" pre-alpha : not complete or compatible svn = r479551, (Nov 27 2006), Windows/ia32/msvc 1310, debug build http://harmony.apache.org

subsection.name: 5. Combining JRE from Built Components
subsection.p:
Class library developers can work with DRLVM or install another compatible VM. For example, you can use the
IBM virtual machine that has been generously made available for the project's development needs by IBM under a non-open source, binary evaluation license. To install the VM, follow the instructions that accompany that VM. You can expand the class library code over the top of the Harmony directory (so that the 'jdk' directories line-up)
subsection.source:
On Windows: $ unzip <path_to_vm_zip> -d ../..
On Linux: $ tar xzf <path_to_vm_tarball> --directory ../..
subsection.p:
To work with the Harmony class library, refer to the
class library subcomponent .
DRLVM developers work with the result of the DRLVM build step, which is a JRE containing DRLVM and the class library.

section.name: Running Java Applications
section.p: Ensure that the JAVA_HOME environment variable is unset, or pointing to the deploy/jre directory.
Run Java applications normally using the launcher in deploy/jre/bin:
section.source: $ deploy/jre/bin/java -showversion -jar helloworld.jar Apache Harmony Launcher: (c) Copyright 1991, 2006 The Apache Software Foundation or its licensors, as applicable. java version "1.5.0" pre-alpha : not complete or compatible svn = r479551, (Nov 27 2006), Windows/ia32/msvc 1310, debug build http://harmony.apache.org Hello world!
